ud5.3:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ud5.3:1.3_0: At that time in Rājagaha there was a leper called Suppabuddha.
ud5.3:1.4_0: He was poor, destitute, and pitiful.
ud5.3:1.5_0: Just then the Buddha was seated, surrounded by a great gathering of people, giving a teaching.
ud5.3:10.1_0: When this was said, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,

ud5.3:11.10_0: There he outshines the other gods in beauty and glory.”
ud5.3:11.1_0: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Suppabuddha used to be a financier’s son right here in Rājagaha.
ud5.3:11.2_0: On his way to visit a park, he saw Tagarasikhi, a Buddha awakened for themselves, entering the city for alms.
ud5.3:11.4_0: “Who is this leper wandering about with his leper’s robe?”
ud5.3:11.5_0: Before leaving, he spat on the ground and turned his left side to Tagarasikhi.
ud5.3:11.6_0: As a result of that deed he burned in hell for many years, for many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of years.
ud5.3:11.7_0: And as a residual result of that same deed, he became a leper right here in Rājagaha, poor, destitute and pitiful.
ud5.3:11.8_0: But owing to faith in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One, he undertook ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
ud5.3:11.9_0: After undertaking these things, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the Thirty-Three.

ud5.3:4.9_0: When the Buddha knew that Suppabuddha’s mind was ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:
ud5.3:5.1_0: Then Suppabuddha saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He rose from his seat and went to the Buddha, and said:
ud5.3:6.2_0: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

ud5.3:6.6_0: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ud5.3:7.1_0: After Suppabuddha had been educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.
ud5.3:7.2_0: But soon after Suppabuddha had left, a cow with a baby calf charged at him and took his life.
ud5.3:8.1_0: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha.
ud5.3:8.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ud5.3:8.3_0: “The leper called Suppabuddha, after being educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, has passed away.
ud5.3:8.4_0: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”
ud5.3:9.1_0: “Mendicants, Suppabuddha was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
ud5.3:9.4_0: With the ending of three fetters, Suppabuddha is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
